args.natural_language_statement: Let A ⊆ X. Show that if C is a connected subspace of X that intersects both A and X \ A, then C intersects Bd A. More formally: Let X be a topological space, A and C subsets of X. If C is connected, C ∩ A ≠ ∅, and C ∩ (X \ A) ≠ ∅, then C ∩ (frontier A) ≠ ∅. Translate to Lean 4 using Mathlib; end the theorem with := by sorry.

args.content:
import Mathlib

/-- If C is a connected subspace of X that meets both A and its complement, then C meets the frontier of A. -/
theorem Munkres_exercise_23_6 {X : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] {A C : Set X}
  (hC : IsConnected C) (h1 : Set.Nonempty (C ∩ A)) (h2 : Set.Nonempty (C ∩ (X \ A))) :
  Set.Nonempty (C ∩ frontier A) := by sorry

  (hC : IsConnected C) (h1 : Set.Nonempty (C ∩ A)) (h2 : Set.Nonempty (C ∩ (X \ A))) :
  Set.Nonempty (C ∩ frontier A) := by sorry

/-- If C is a connected subspace of X that meets both A and its complement, then C meets the frontier of A. -/

args.content:
import Mathlib

/-- If C is a connected subspace of X that meets both A and its complement, then C meets the frontier of A. -/
theorem Munkres_exercise_23_6 {X : Type _} [TopologicalSpace X] {A C : Set X}
  (hC : IsConnected C) (h1 : Set.Nonempty (C ∩ A)) (h2 : Set.Nonempty (C ∩ (Aᶜ))) :
  Set.Nonempty (C ∩ frontier A) := by sorry
